title: Using "Let" and "Shall we"
content:
Suppose we want to call our friends for some action, we will say тАЬLet us goтАЭ, тАЬLet us start lunchтАЭ etc.
In Marathi such form is created by suffixing тАЬрдКрдпрд╛тАЭ (UyA) to the verb. Also generally sentence is started with рдЪрд▓рд╛ (chalA) which is a kind of exclamation or call for action.
Examples:
LetтАЩs play:- рдЪрд▓рд╛, рдЖрдкрдг рдЦреЗрд│реВрдпрд╛ (chalA, ApaN kheLUyA)
LetтАЩs go:- рдЪрд▓рд╛, рдЖрдкрдг рдЬрд╛рдКрдпрд╛ (chalA, ApaN jAUyA)
тАЬрдЖрдкрдгтАЭ can be omitted.
LetтАЩs speak:- рдЪрд▓рд╛, рдмреЛрд▓реВрдпрд╛
Negative sentence:
The negative sentence can be formed by adding тАЬрдирдХреЛтАЭ (nako) before the verb. Generally, рдЪрд▓рд╛ (chalA) will not be used as we are not calling for any action.
Examples:
LetтАЩs not play:- рдЖрдкрдг рдирдХреЛ рдЦреЗрд│реВрдпрд╛ (ApaN nako kheLUyA)

title: Using May to express wish
content:
In English we say тАЬMay God bless youтАЭ, тАЬMay he help youтАЭ, тАЬMay door open soonтАЭ. Here we have used тАЬmayтАЭ express wish.
In Marathi, we say such wishes by appending рдУ(o) for singular and рдУрдд(ot) to plural.
e.g.
for verb do i.e. рдХрд░рдгреЗ(karaNe) forms are рдХрд░реЛ(karo) and рдХрд░реЛрдд (karot)
for verb speak i.e. рдмреЛрд▓рдгреЗ(bolaNe) forms are рдмреЛрд▓реЛ(bolo) and рдмреЛрд▓реЛрдд (bolot)
For verbs not ending with рдЕ(a) we append рд╡реЛ(vo) for singular and рд╡реЛрдд(vot) for plural.
for verb give i.e.рджреЗрдгреЗ (deNe) forms are рджреЗрд╡реЛ ( devo ) and рджреЗрд╡реЛрдд ( devot )
for verb become i.e рд╣реЛрдгреЗ ( hoNe ) forms are рд╣реЛрд╡реЛ ( hovo ) and рд╣реЛрд╡реЛрдд ( hovot )
May God bless you -> рджреЗрд╡ рддреБрдореНрд╣рд╛рд▓рд╛ рдЖрд╢рд┐рд░реНрд╡рд╛рдж рджреЗрд╡реЛ ( dev tumhAlA AshirvAd devo )
May he help you -> рддреЛ рддреБрдореНрд╣рд╛рд▓рд╛ рдорджрдд рдХрд░реЛ ( to tumhAlA madat karo )
May they help you -> рддреЗ рддреБрдореНрд╣рд╛рд▓рд╛ рдорджрдд рдХрд░реЛрдд ( te tumhAlA madat karot )
May new year be happy to you -> рдирд╡реАрди рд╡рд░реНрд╖ рд╕реБрдЦрджрд╛рдпрдХ рдЕрд╕реЛ ( navIn varSh sukhadAyak aso )
May shop open soon -> рджреБрдХрд╛рди рд▓рд╡рдХрд░ рдЙрдШрдбреЛ ( dukAn lavakar ughaDo)
Give above is the word to word translation of тАЬMay God bless youтАЭ, but as custom, in Marathi, we say рджреЗрд╡ рддреБрдордЪрдВ рднрд▓рдВ рдХрд░реЛ ( dev tumachaM bhalaM karo )
In Marathi, we generally use this form only for third-person. Not with first or second person i.e. not with рдореА, рдЖрдореНрд╣реА, рддреВ, рддреБрдореНрд╣реА.
So In English, we can form a sentence like тАЬMay you help meтАЭ which will be in Marathi as рддреВ рдорд▓рд╛ рдорджрдд рдХрд░реЛ ( tU malA madat karo ). So though grammatically perfect, it sounds a bit irregular in Marathi.
Wish / To wish
тАЬWishтАЭ (noun) -> рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ (ichCA) it is feminine-singular noun. To wish -> рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ рдЕрд╕рдгреЗ (ichCA asaNe)
The sentence using рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ рдЕрд╕рдгреЗ (ichCA asaNe) is similar to saying тАЬIt is my wish thatтАж may/shouldтАжтАЭ
I wish he goes to school -> It is my wish that he should go to school -> рдорд╛рдЭреА рдЕрд╢реА рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ рдЖрд╣реЗ рдХреА рддреЛ рд╢рд╛рд│реЗрдд рдЧреЗрд▓рд╛ рдкрд╛рд╣рд┐рдЬреЗ.(mAjhI ashI ichChA Ahe kI to shALet gelA pAhije.)
He wishes Kaushik wins -> It is his wish that may Kaushik win -> рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪреА рдЕрд╢реА рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ рдЖрд╣реЗ рдХреА рдХреМрд╢рд┐рдХ рдЬрд┐рдВрдХреЛ(tyAchI ashI ichChA Ahe kI Kaushik jiMko)
It is his wish that Kaushik should win -> рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪреА рдЕрд╢реА рдЗрдЪреНрдЫрд╛ рдЖрд╣реЗ рдХреА рдХреМрд╢рд┐рдХрдиреЗ рдЬрд┐рдВрдХрд╛рд╡реЗ (tyAchI ashI ichChA Ahe kI kaushikane jiMkAve)
With рдЕрдХрд░реНрдордХ(akarmak) verbs; when expressing wish; we create verb form as per gender and multiplicity of
subject
Subject
verb+ form of "рд╡рд╛" depending on gender and multiplicity of subject i.e.
рдЖрд╡рд╛-рдЖрд╡реА-рдЖрд╡реЗ-рдЖрд╡реЗ-рдЖрд╡реНрдпрд╛-рдЖрд╡реА  (AvA-AvI-Ave-Ave-AvyA-AvI)

Examples:

content:
Sentences using the phrase

title: Using тАЬShouldтАЭ
content:
In English we use тАЬshouldтАЭ verb to indicate the desired behavior.
e.g. тАЬHe should go to schoolтАЭ; тАЬYou should take medicineтАЭ; тАЬThey should not have done thisтАЭ
In Marathi sentence formation is :
Form of noun/pronoun
as in simple past tense

рдЖрд╣реЗ

title: Using "To mean". How to ask meaning in Marathi
content:
In English, we use the verb тАЬTo MeanтАЭ e.g. тАЬWhat does it meanтАЭ, тАЬWhat is its meaningтАЭ. тАЬI did not mean itтАЭ etc.
In Marathi тАЬmeaningтАЭ is рдЕрд░реНрде(arth).
In Marathi the translation of sentence тАЬwhat does it meanтАЭ is actually similar to translation of тАЬwhat is its meaningтАЭ
1)What does it mean -> What is its meaning -> рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛ рдЕрд░реНрде рдХрд╛рдп (tyAchA arth kAy)
2)What does that signboard mean -> What is meaning of that signboard ->рддреНрдпрд╛ рдкрд╛рдЯреАрдЪрд╛ рдЕрд░реНрде рдХрд╛рдп ( tyA pATIchA arth kAy )
3)What did his speech mean -> What was the meaning of his speech -> рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛ рднрд╛рд╖рдгрд╛рдЪрд╛ рдЕрд░реНрде рдХрд╛рдп рд╣реЛрддрд╛ (tyAchyA bhAShaNAchA arth kAy hotA)
When you are asking the meaning of some word you can ask it, in short, using рдореНрд╣рдгрдЬреЗ рдХрд╛рдп (mhaNaje kAy ) as follows:
What does тАЬencyclopediaтАЭ mean -> тАЬencyclopediaтАЭ рдореНрд╣рдгрдЬреЗ рдХрд╛рдп (mhaNaje kAy )
What does тАЬSundarтАЭ mean in Marathi -> рдорд░рд╛рдареАрдордзреЗ рд╕реБрдВрджрд░ рдореНрд╣рдгрдЬреЗ рдХрд╛рдп (marAThImadhe suMdar mhaNaje kAy )
In English, we also say тАЬI did not mean itтАЭ
, тАЬHe did not mean insulting youтАЭ. Such sentences are said bit differently in Marathi.
I did mean it -> My saying meant this -> рдорд╛рдЭреНрдпрд╛ рдмреЛрд▓рдгреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛ рдЕрд░реНрде рд╣рд╛ рд╣реЛрддрд╛ (mAjhyA bolaNyAchA arth hA hotA)
I did not mean it -> My saying did not mean this -> рдорд╛рдЭреНрдпрд╛ рдмреЛрд▓рдгреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛ рдЕрд░реНрде рд╣рд╛ рдирд╡реНрд╣рддрд╛ (mAjhyA bolaNyAchA arth hA navhatA)
When we use тАЬTo meanтАЭ to indicate purpose
, it is said differently in Marathi.
Purpose in Marathi is рдЙрджреНрджреЗрд╢(uddesh)
тАЬHe did not mean hurting youтАЭ -> His purpose was not to hurt you -> рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛ рдЙрджреНрджреЗрд╢ рддреБрдореНрд╣рд╛рд▓рд╛ рджреБрдЦрд╡рдгреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛ рдирд╡реНрд╣рддрд╛ (tyAchA uddesh tumhAlA dukhavaNyAchA navhatA)
I meant to insult him -> My purpose was to insult him ->рдорд╛рдЭрд╛ рдЙрджреНрджреЗрд╢ рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛ рдЕрдкрдорд╛рди рдХрд░рдгреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛ рд╣реЛрддрд╛ (majhA uddesh tyAchA apamAn karaNyAchA hotA)

title: Using verb "To remember" in Marathi
content:
In Marathi тАЬ
To remember
тАЭ is
рдЖрдард╡рдгреЗ
(AThavaNe)
There are three ways in which we use the verb тАЬto rememberтАЭ
1) Suppose a teacher meets his student after many years and says тАЬYou are from the batch of 1970, right? I remember you.тАЭ
2) A student living in a hostel writes a letter to his mother; тАЬWhenever I eat food at canteen I remember dishes you used to cook. I miss you.тАЭ
3) A person helped you in your bad time. You will say to him; тАЬThank you, friend. I will always remember your favorтАЭ.
In all the sentence we have used verb remember, but there is a subtle difference in every use.
In the first sentence, you say you have not forgotten something.
In the second case, you say one event triggers or brings back the memory of some other event.
In the third sentence, you explicitly assure of keeping something in mind.
In Marathi sentence is formed differently in every case.

title: Verbs which use preposition "To" with subject and verb form as per object
content:
Before I begin, let me thank my student Ram Prakash for giving me the idea of this lesson.
Verbs which use the preposition тАЬToтАЭ with subject and verb form as per object
Consider the verbs тАЬTo rememberтАЭ, тАЬTo likeтАЭ, тАЬTo getтАЭ. In English, sentences will be formed as follows
I remember He remembers, They rememberтАж
I like, He likes, They likeтАж
I get, He gets, They getтАж
As you see, the verb form changes as per the subject in the sentences (I, He, They in the above sentences).
In Marathi few verbs are exceptional. For such verbs the sentence structure is different.
The preposition тАЬToтАЭ is used with the subject. And the verb form is created as per the gender and multiplicity of the object.
тАЬTo getтАЭ i.e. рдорд┐рд│рдгреЗ(miLaNe) is one such verb
e.g.
тАЬI get a prizeтАЭ will be translated like saying тАЬTo me a prize getsтАЭ
тАЬI get 10 prizesтАЭ will be translated like saying тАЬTo me 10 prizes getтАЭ.
Observe that change in verb form from тАЬgetsтАЭ to тАЬgetтАЭ when object changed from singular (a prize) to plural (10 prizes) & preposition тАЬToтАЭ with the subject.
So in Marathi
I get a prize -> To me a prize gets -> рдорд▓рд╛ рдмрдХреНрд╖рд┐рд╕ рдорд┐рд│рддреЗ (malA bakShis miLate)

title: Vowels, Consonants in Marathi and their pronunciation
content: Pronunciation conventions for Marathi alphabets. Learn vowels, consonants, and key pronunciation rules.
intro: Pronunciation conventions for Marathi alphabets. Each letter represents a consistent sound. Use the speaker buttons to hear pronunciation.

blocks.heading: Consonant Pronunciation Notes (рд╡реНрдпрдВрдЬрди)
blocks.content: Each consonant combines with a vowel sound to make syllables (e.g., рдХ + рдЕ = рдХ /ka/). Retroflex sounds (рдЯ, рда, рдб, рдв, рдг, рд│) use tongue curled back (harder), represented by capital style in transliteration when needed. Some consonants like рдЩ /с╣Е/ and рдЮ /├▒a/ are nasal stops (nose sound) and different from рди /na/.

blocks.heading: Key Pronunciation Rules
blocks.content:
**One letter = one sound:** Each Marathi letter generally represents a consistent sound.

**Vowel quality:** рдЗ /i/ is like "i" in sit, рдИ /─л/ is like "ee" in see. рдЙ /u/ and рдК /┼л/ are like "oo" in foot and cool. рдП /e/ is a mid-front sound like ay in say. рдР /ai/ is a diphthong like ai in time. рдУ /o/ is like o in go, рдФ /au/ is like ow in cow.

**Retroflex vs dental:** t/T, d/D represent retroflex vs dental articulations (hard vs soft).

**Schwa behavior:** The inherent "a" vowel is often not pronounced at the end in real speech (schwa deletion variations).

Go through it once. You may not remember all pronunciation now. But as and when you will use it in the sentence, come back to these rules and check it. After a few days, you will remember it automatically.

title: Welcome to Learn Marathi from Hindi
content:
Learning Marathi through Hindi is very easy. Being conversant with Hindi has many advantages while learning Marathi.
1) Both languages use the same script i.e. Devanagari. So by default, you can read Marathi.
2) The beauty of Devanagari with respect to the Roman script is that the pronunciation is the same as what it is written. So you will not make mistake in pronunciation of Marathi words. So that part is automatically taken care of
3) Mostly the sentence formation rules (e.g. a sequence of the noun, verb etc.) in Marathi is the same as Hindi. So generally you map a Hindi sentence into Marathi word by word.
In short, you know Hindi means 80% you already know Marathi.
So in this coming lessons, we will try to cover up those 20% !!
In my blog for learning Marathi through English(
http://kaushiklele-learnmarathi.blogspot.in
)
I had explained grammar in detail. English is a completely different language, I thought it necessary to introduce a learner with grammar then slowly moving to simple sentences and then big conversations.
But as you know Hindi, I would directly start with Marathi sentences. You will be able to extract the grammar automatically. Wherever required I will explain the difference.
Also, many people who know Hindi want to grasp simple sentences quickly and develop their skills by more listening and reading. For them, learning grammar in detail is a discouraging factor.
So the approach is completely changing while learning Marathi from Hindi.
For some examples transliteration is given in Roman script is as well. This is for the convenience of search-ability on internet.

title: Welcome to world of Marathi
content:
Hello friends, welcome to my blog, тАЬLearn Marathi through English-HindiтАЭ.Here I am trying to introduce you to the fundamentals of Marathi through English. But at some places, I have taken the help of examples from Hindi.
Hindi and Marathi both follow the same script i.e. Devanagari. The pronunciation of letters is the same. So those who can read-write Hindi, for them reading Marathi is easy. They will save their time learning pronunciation. So if you know Hindi, this journey to learn Marathi will be comparatively easy. But those who do not know Hindi need not feel upset, but they just need to put little more effort learning script and pronunciation.
My own experience says that reading the language from its own script helps a lot. So learn the Devanagari script first. So learning Marathi will be easier if you read it directly from Devanagari instead of Romanized. For most of the examples, transliteration is given in Roman script is as well. This is for the convenience of search-ability on the internet.

is
рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛
рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪрд╛
is masculine ending with рдЖ (A) So as per above rules its form becomes
рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛
This way you can try creating sentences. There are many exceptions to the above rules, you will sense it as and when you will read more and more Marathi.
Another Style. Extension of above
As we had seen in the previous post, when the preposition is used with pronoun the words become рддреНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рдареА (tyAchyAsAThI), рддреАрдЪреНрдпрд╛рдореБрд│реЗ(tIchyAmuLe), рддреНрдпрд╛рдВрдЪреНрдпрд╛рдирдВрддрд░ ( tyAMchyAnaMtar ), etc. As you can see there is рдЪреНрдпрд╛ (chyA) in every word. Because of this, some people tend to use рдЪреНрдпрд╛( chyA ) before every preposition used with a noun.
e.g.
For fort -> рдХрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реНрдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рдареА (killyAsAThI ) or рдХрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛рд╕рд╛рдареА (killyAchyAsAThI )
On bucket -> рдмрд╛рджрд▓реАрд╡рд░ (badalIvar ) or рдмрд╛рджрд▓реАрдЪреНрдпрд╛рд╡рд░ (badalIchyAvar)
Under table -> рдЯреЗрдмрд▓рд╛рдЦрд╛рд▓реА (TebalAkhAlI ) or рдЯреЗрдмрд▓рд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛рдЦрд╛рд▓реА (TebalAchyAkhAlI )
Both ways are right, but try to use first way i.e. without adding рдЪреНрдпрд╛ (chyA) to preposition
Note for preposition In/at
In the table, it is written as рдЖрдд/рдд (At/t )
When you are using рдЪреНрдпрд╛( chyA ) with рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдп рд░реВрдк (sAmAnya rUp); we use word тАЬрдЖрдд(At)тАЭ
But if we do not use рдЪреНрдпрд╛( chyA ) then we just append тАЬрдд(t)тАЭ to word form.
e.g.
In/At fort -> рдХрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реНрдпрд╛рдд (killyAt ) or рдХрд┐рд▓реНрд▓реНрдпрд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛ рдЖрдд (killyAchyA At )
In/At bucket -> рдмрд╛рджрд▓реАрдд (badalIvar ) or рдмрд╛рджрд▓реАрдЪреНрдпрд╛ рдЖрдд (badalIchyAvar) etc.
For тАЬat homeтАЭ we generally say рдШрд░рд╛рдд (gharAt) or a special way as рдШрд░реА(gharI).
So some people may ask; тАЬwhat is the difference between тАЬрдЖрддтАЭ and тАЬрдИтАЭ?
To be precise; тАЬрдЖрддтАЭ is used to indicate position тАЬinsideтАЭ and тАЬрдИтАЭ is used to indicate preposition тАЬatтАЭ
e.g.
Gold is buried inside home ->рд╕реЛрдиреЗ рдШрд░рд╛рдд рдкреБрд░рд▓реЗ рдЖрд╣реЗ. (sone gharAt purale Ahe.
Tomorrow I am at home -> рдЙрджреНрдпрд╛ рдореА рдШрд░реА рдЖрд╣реЗ (udyA mI gharI Ahe)
But you can find both forms used invariably.
In very few cases тАЬрд╡рд░тАЭ(var) is also used to indicate preposition тАЬatтАЭ.
There is no precise rule when people prefer тАЬрд╡рд░тАЭ(var). But as per my observation when they are giving not-so-precise information or indicating a surrounding they use тАЬрд╡рд░тАЭ(var).
e.g.
I saw John at the airport -> рдореА рдЬреЙрдирд▓рд╛ рдПрдЕрд░рдкреЛрд░реНрдЯрд╡рд░/рд╡рд┐рдорд╛рдирддрд│рд╛рд╡рд░ рдмрдШрд┐рддрд▓рдВ (mI j~onalA earaporTavar/vimAnataLAvar baghitalaM)
Ladies met at the village well -> рдмрд╛рдпрдХрд╛ рдЧрд╛рд╡рд╛рдЪреНрдпрд╛ рд╡рд┐рд╣рд┐рд░реАрд╡рд░ рднреЗрдЯрд▓реНрдпрд╛ (bAyakA gAvAchyA vihirIvar bheTalyA)
Children are playing at/nearby river -> рдореБрд▓реЗ рдирджреАрд╡рд░ рдЦреЗрд│рдд рдЖрд╣реЗрдд (mule nadIvar kheLat Ahet)
So more you read Marathi you may get more examples.
